titleStmt.title: Time scales and moments of listening effort revealed in pupillometry

analytic.title: Time scales and moments of listening effort revealed in pupillometry

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: This paper offers a collection of observations that highlight the value of timecourse data in pupillometry and points out ways in which these observations create deeper understanding of listening effort. The main message is that listening effort should be considered on a moment-tomoment basis rather than as a singular amount. A review of various studies and re-analysis of data reveal distinct signatures of effort before a stimulus, during a stimulus, in the moments after a stimulus, and changes over whole experimental testing sessions. Collectively these observations motivate questions that extend beyond the "amount" of effort, toward understanding how long the effort lasts, and how precisely someone can allocate effort at specific points in time or reduce effort at other times. Apparent disagreements between studies are reconsidered as informative lessons about stimulus selection and the nature of pupil dilation as a reflection of decision making rather than the difficulty of sensory encoding. Learning Objectives After reading this article, the leaner will be able to 1) Discuss listening effort as a concept that changes moment-to-moment rather than being a singular amount 2) Identify different timing landmarks in pupillometric data on listening effort 3) Determine the experimental stimuli that are more or less likely to elicit meaningful and interpretable pupil dilations

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The study of listening effort continues to grow, as scientists and clinicians gain a deeper appreciation of its effect on the listening experience, and as technology enables the mapping of effort to quantifiable metrics. Although it is reasonable to ask how much effort is exerted, equally valid questions can be asked about how long the effort lasts, and how precisely someone can allocate effort at specific points in time and reduce effort at other times. Of the numerous ways to measure the effort of understanding speech, pupillometry has the valuable feature of being a time-series measure that could potentially address these questions. Pupillometrythe measurement of changes in pupil dilationhas been used as an objective measure of cognitive load (Zekveld et al. 2018;Beatty 1982a), and underwent a resurgence in recent decades as eye tracking technology became more widely adopted and automated. With dilations occurring at sub-second time scales, pupillometry is suitable for tracking how effort changes on a momentto-moment basis before, during, and after the listening process (Weirda et al. 2012). This enables an experimenter an alternative to characterizing effort as a singular end product of a sequence of events, as is available in reaction-time measurements and subjective reporting.

Additionally, for those working with participants who use electronic devices such as cochlear implants and hearing aids, pupillometry is unaffected by electrical artifacts and requires no physical preparation of the participant. For those interested in speech perception by people who have hearing difficulty, pupillometry and other measures of effort can be valuable to demonstrate that being able to repeat a sentence correctly (as in most clinical and laboratory tasks) is not an accurate reflection of the effort needed to understand that sentence (Winn & Teece 2021).

The pupillary response is thought to emanate from the neural structures that are associated with arousal, engagement, and decision making (Satterthwaite et al. 2007;Eckstein et al. 2017;de Gee et al. 2017;, which make this measurement attractive from the standpoint of accessing the cognitive aftermath of listening rather than simply being a readout of the sensory encoding itself. Pupil size scales with the strength of cholinergic and adrenergic cortical activity across the cortex (Reimer et al. 2016). Pupil size also happens to be a reliable indicator of the cortical changes induced by direct vagus nerve stimulation (Mridha et al. 2021).

Together these observations suggest that pupil size reflects the cortical networks that support top-down optimization of sensory encoding. Put another way, this would reflect intentional allocation of resources in a goal-directed task, which fits the definition of effort offered by Pichora-Fuller et al. (2016), adapted from the model of attention described by Kahneman (1973).
The added value of pupillometry over intelligibility scores.

In clinical and laboratory assessments, speech intelligibility is evaluated as the percentage of utterances that are correctly repeated. Although this measure is expedient for expressing performance as a percentage, there are other relevant skills and processes in speech recognition, which are better expressed as a change in effort rather than a change in the ability to repeat words. For example, pupil dilations can demonstrate the effort of processing grammatical and syntactic violations (Demberg & Sayeed 2016), lexical competition (Schmidtke 2014), word frequency (Kuchinke et al. 2007;, the interaction of word frequency with bilingualism (van Rijn et al. 2012), and resolving different meaning that arises with conflicting prosody (Engelhardt et al. 2010). A listener must also predict upcoming words, understand non-literal meanings of words, ascertain the talker's confidence, detect sarcasm, differentiate the emphasis or new important information in an utterance, and detect when it is appropriate to respond or close the conversation. These skills are not evaluated by one's ability to correctly repeat words or sentences. The skills are worth studying despite the added complication of measurement, because they are integral for successful everyday communication (Kandoorp et al. 2017). A separate, arguably more important justification for measuring effort directly is that people with hearing difficulty report how effort is essential to communicate, and can impact their sense of social connectedness versus isolation (Hughes et al. 2018). The use of effort to defray the perceived sense of emotional burden or dependence was described in vivid detail in patients interviewed by Hughes et al. (2018), who bring to light the importance of understanding effort.

div.head: Goals of this paper
div.p: There are three main themes of this paper. First, different time scales and timing landmarks of information in pupillometry data are discussed in order to highlight the rich potential value of looking at when effort happens rather than just how much effort is occurring. This is followed by a discussion of stimulus selection and design, and then a large-scale reflection on the questions that drive listening effort research as well as questions that drive criticisms of this research. The current paper will not attempt to comprehensively review all of the advice on experiment design from previous publications, but will instead focus on some of the under-appreciated aspects of pupil data analysis and stimulus design that might be particularly useful for experimenters studying speech recognition, especially in those who have hearing difficulty. For more comprehensive discussion of experimental methodological considerations, readers are referred to numerous publications that serve as guidance to experimenters conducting pupillometry studies (Schmidtke et al. 2017;Steinhauer et al. 2022), which typically also review important findings along the way.

div.head: Time scales of listening effort
div.p: For many pupillometry studies, it is sufficient to report summarized measurements such as peak dilation and mean dilation (c.f. Zekveld et al. 2010;Wendt et al. 2018;Ayasse et al. 2021). However, there is much to gain by observing the full time course of dilation, and by designing experiments with this goal explicitly in mind. Steinhauer et al. (2022) transform this notion into a direct call to action for experimenters, encouraging the illustration of the time-series data in pupillometry experiments rather than providing a summary table of extracted features like peaks and latencies. The following sections examine dilations at particular common landmarks during experimental trials, in search of potentially useful distinctions that aid understanding. In the process, several data sets from previous and ongoing studies are discussed in order to highlight how pupil-based measures of effort can be analyzed over shorter or longer time scales in order to influence experiment design, interpretation of data, or interpretation of what effort is. Figure 1 previews the various landmarks that will be discussed, with particular points of interest highlighted in each panel.

[[ Figure 1 here ]] Figure 1. Simulated patterns of pupillometry data showing distinct patterns that appear at different landmarks or scales of timing, in response to a 4-second sentence beginning at time 0.

In each panel, the two lines reflect different hypothetical conditions. Panels A, B, C, and D illustrate dilation patterns that emerge at earlier to later parts of the trial (pre-stimulus baseline, dilation slope, retention interval, verbal response, respectively). Panels E and F illustrate a distinction in dilation latency that is either clearly separated or blended together. Panel G is a full time course that has a particular window of analysis that is expanded into a sub-panel where the subtle differences in dilation onset are observed. Panel H shows a longer time scale of dilations lasting over a minute rather than the ~14 second patterns shown in earlier panels. In panel H, the overall pupil size as well as the size and compactness of phasic dilations all change across multiple trials.

div.head: Dilations before listening
div.p: Pupil size can signify the anticipation of upcoming events. For example, increased dilation is observed at the onset of the notification that the next trial will be more challenging (McCloy et al. 2017), suggesting that effort can be pre-allocated (or at least that arousal can precede the actual stimulus). Baseline pupil size can be a reliable indicator of optimal states for sensory detection (McGinley et al. 2015;Reimer et al. 2016) and lapses of attention (van den Brink et al. 2016). Pupil size is also tightly linked with the locus coeruleus system (Aston-Jones & Cohen), whose activity is related to perceptual learning (Glennon et al. 2019). The general trend is for smaller pre-stimulus pupil size to be associated with better task performance, although Bönitz et al. (2021) observed differences in pre-stimulus baseline pupil size within a sequence of sentences and suggested that it reflected buildup of cognitive load during the sequence. Collectively, these studies imply that pupil size should not be understood merely as a property evoked by a stimulus, but rather a property that reflects a state of arousal that is contextualized by the participant's expectations and momentary attention.

div.head: Dilations elicited by noise before a sentence
div.p: The appreciation of pre-stimulus pupil size has important implications for studies of speech recognition in noiseespecially when the noise begins before the onset of the target speech, as is typical. If the experimenter keeps the target speech level constant but adjusts difficulty by changing the noise intensity, then the pre-speech baseline is at risk for being affected by the experimental condition. Consistent with this, Russo et al. (2020) illustrated data showing dilation to the leading noise itself, followed by a second dilation in response to a spoken word (illustrated in Figure 1 panel A). A louder pre-stimulus leading noise will likely increase pupil size by mere virtue of sensation level (Liao et al. 2016), and therefore the subsequent baseline-corrected values will be compressed. Mathôt et al. (2022) warn against this practice in a thorough review of pupillometry experiment design. Despite concerns about an unwieldy interaction, several studies (Zekveld et al. 2010;Koelewijn et al. 2012;Parthasarathy et al. 2020) presented speech-in-noise stimuli where the leading noise (rather than the speech) was varied in intensity to achieve target signal to noise ratios, where the data still produced interpretable results in line with the hypotheses. Conversely, Kadem et al. (2020) kept pre-stimulus noise intensity constant and altered the intensity of the speech, and identified various subtle effects of ambiguity on effort as it emerged during the sentence. Although each of these studies produced valuable knowledge, the method used by Kadem et al. has the advantage of a common reference point for each stimulus comparison, as there were no differences in pre-stimulus audio that would have affected baseline activity.

In addition to the mundane arousal elicited by louder noises, another potentially interesting effect might arise in a variable-noise-before-stimulus experiment setup: the participant could immediately recognize the difficulty of the upcoming stimulus merely by detecting an increase in the leading noise level. After all, higher noise level would signal that the upcoming speech would be more difficult, so there might be a different momentary disposition of listening. This potential convolution of factors has not been fully elucidated in the literature. To cut down on exact timing of anticipation, Koelewijn et al. (2015) introduced some variability in the duration of leading noise, with durations of 2, 4 or 6 seconds preceding the target speech, as well as all-noise catch trials, finding no significant differences in pupil dilation or baseline in the case of unpredictable speech onset.

div.head: Dilations during listening
div.p: Studies that only report peak pupil dilation and peak latency miss potentially useful information about the growth of pupil size up to that point. The rate of growth of pupil dilation can reflect physiological differences that occur during the listening process, which can add extra detail to measures that reflect a sum total of effort that has accumulated over time. These changes in rateillustrated in Figure 1 panel Blikely reflect the difficulty of actual auditory encoding or the vigilance needed to convert the signal into something understandable. The value of this factor will vary across studies. For example, in a short-term memory task, pupil size grows at a rather constant rate (Klingner et al. 2011), so the rate of growth adds little to a measure of peak dilation. However, in other studies, the difference in peak dilation is accompanied by a change in the rate of dilation as well. For example, Winn et al. (2015) and Miles et al. (2017) observed systematic increases in the growth rate of pupil dilation during the presentation of sentences with corresponding systematic degradations in spectral resolution.
The rate of dilation can also be tightly related to the duration of the stimulus, suggesting listeners' anticipation of the stimulus durations (Winn & Teece 2020).

Dilation rate is also influenced by the type of masking noise (Koelewijn et al. 2012) and by reward-driven motivation during difficult trials (Koelewijn et al. 2021). There is shallower dilation growth rate when sentences are heard by participants listening in their native accent compared to a non-native accent (McLaughlin & Van Engen 2020), and those differences are similar in scope to those observed by Winn (2016) when comparing native-listener perception of sentences with predictable versus unpredictable semantic content (yielding lower and higher dilation, respectively during the presentation of the sentence). Borghini and Hazan (2020) replicated this interaction of findings, and further demonstrated that the effect of semantic context was indeed limited to native listeners and did not extend to non-native listeners, suggesting a difference in real-time processing effort rather than mere differences in success after a sentence was already spoken. The impact of predictability on real-time effort extends beyond speech as well; Milne et al. (2021) observed reduction of pupil dilation at the onset of coherent structure in an auditory stimulus consisting of tone pips. Each of these studies demonstrates that pupillometry can be used to interpret whether effort is engaged more rapidly or slowly across time.

div.head: Dilations after listening
div.p: Considering the rapid continuous nature of conversational speech, there might be a significant role for the duration of effort, since a listener who is dwelling on one utterance might be at risk for missing the next utterance that comes immediate after. Numerous studies show a wide range of factors that affect pupil size following peak dilation, suggesting that there is value to thinking of effort outside the scope of sensory encoding. Post-peak changes in dilationas illustrated in Figure 1 panel Ccan capture the effort spent handling various kinds of stimulus ambiguity, both semantic (Kadem et al. 2020), as well as syntactic (Wendt et al. 2016).

Conversely, phonetic ambiguity is observed on a more rapid timescale that does not continue past the end of the sentence for listeners with typical hearing (Winn & Teece 2021), but does persist for listeners with cochlear implants (Winn & Teece, submitted).

Post-peak dilations might reflect the listener's knowledge that the perception was imperfect, as there is sustained dilation after peak dilation in cases of incorrect responses in a degraded-speech task (Winn et al. 2015;Zhang et al. 2021). McHaney et al. (2021) further clarified that this effect was strongest later in a testing session and more evident in participants with higher working memory, implicating a role of continued processing following sensory perception. When data collected by Winn et al. (2015) contained only trials with correct responses, the differences that emerged in peak dilations re-converged, suggesting that following the variable difficulty of the auditory encoding, effort of consolidating and reporting the sentence was rather similar among the various degraded conditions tested, so long as the correct perception emerged.

Across listening conditions with systematic increase in the number of errors, there is a corresponding increase in the pupil size after the sentence (Wendt et al. 2018). When the listener gives a verbal response that is obviously wrong because of linguistic incoherence, there is a strong increase in dilation, particularly after the sentence (Winn & Teece 2021). Continued dilation past the end of a sentence might reflect the same principles revealed by Bradshaw (1968) whose data from a mental arithmetic task showed elevated dilation until the moment of solution, presumably because participants continued to try to solve the problem.

Post-peak pupil dilations have been vital to the interpretation of a series of experiments that examined the use of context during sentence recognition by people who use cochlear implants. Sentences from the Revised Speech in Noise test (Bilger et al. 1984) were presented at their original speaking rate or digitally modified to be 40% slower in a study by Winn and Teece (2020). In a previous study, Winn and Moore (2018) presented the same sentences modified to be 20% longer than the original recordings to similar listening groups, thus allowing a comparison of three artificial speaking rates shown in Figure 2. The degree of difference between dilations evoked by high-and low-context sentences systematically increases as the speech is slowed. That difference is observed primarily after the sentence for listeners with cochlear implants, in contrast to data from listeners with normal hearing, who begin to show this difference before the sentence is over. Notably, these insights are not gained by measurements of peak dilation and peak latency. between responses for high-and low-context sentences as the rate gets slower, and the overall larger distinction between those stimulus types for listeners with NH.

Post-peak pupil dilation can lend insight on the difficulties of processing speech in a native or non-native language. For example, in a study by Francis et al. (2018) involving native speakers of Dutch who also spoke English, post-peak pupil dilation was lowest when both the target and masker were speaking Dutch, suggesting that a native language might be easier to both attend and ignore. That post-peak dilation level increased when the masker was speaking English, increased more when the target speech was English, and increased most of all when both the target and masker were speaking English. Notably, the differences in peak dilation and peak latencythe traditional outcome measureswere minimal by comparison, further highlighting the unique added value of post-utterance pupil dilation and time-series data analysis in general.

In addition to dilations that occur after full sentences, some post-stimulus effects have been observed with single words as well. For example, Kuchinsky et al. (2013) found sustained dilation for words in harder noise conditions, particularly when those words have more lexical competitors (such as pat-mat-bat). Lexical processing can also be more effortful if target items are less frequent in the language (Kuchinke et al. 2007). Additionally, Colby and McMurray (2021) have observed sustained effects for single words that are spectrally degraded. These results are consistent responses elicited by accented speech (Poretta & Tucker 2019), and speech with talker variability (Lim et al. 2021).

div.head: Post-stimulus effort as a signature of memory encoding
div.p: It is tempting to think of elevated effort as being necessarily disadvantageous. However, despite the patterns described in the preceding sections, increased dilation after a stimulus is not uniformly indicative of unsuccessful listening. Some dilation at the end of a stimulus might signify a requisite amount of effort to encode the stimulus and store it into memory. For example, Zhang et al. (2021) used a word-recall task and found smaller dilation during trials where the word was ultimately forgotten. This pattern was also observed in previous studies by Kucewicz et al. (2018), and , whose data suggest that the dilation response could be considered to be a memory-strength signal. Consistent with these observations, Ackermann et al. (2019) showed that increased pupil dilation during novel word exposure was associated with better learning of those words by children. de Gee et al. (2022) suggest that increased dilation can reflect strategic use of effort that adapts to the expected reward. These results suggest that the notion of elevated effort as indicated by pupil size is oversimplified if always viewed negatively; the pupil response may indicate 'salience' or engagement that can aid processing.

div.head: Dilations during verbal responses
div.p: In listen-and-repeat studies of effort, it is common to observe dilation during verbal response that exceeds peak dilation during listening. The nature of that second large dilationillustrated in Figure 1 panel Dcould reveal insight about the mental processing of the preceding sound. Figure 3 shows an example from a real dataset where some extra insight can be gained when the window of analysis extends 7 or more seconds beyond the stimulus. For both listener groups in this study, there is larger dilation following stimuli that are more demanding (in this case, needing to remember three digits in addition to a sentence). However, that elevated dilation extends forward in time differently across the two listener groups. For the listeners with normal hearing, dilation from the more difficult condition extends for about an extra second relative to the easier condition, while for the listeners with cochlear implants, the dilation for the difficult condition extends for two seconds relative to the easier condition. Stated differently, the dilation for verbal responses to the sentence alone recovered toward baseline more quickly for the CI listeners. For both groups, re-convergence of dilation patterns for these two conditions occurs more than seven seconds past the end of the stimulus. The source of this difference cannot be fully understood just from this dataset, since the factors that likely contribute to the effort of speech production were not prospectively controlled in the study. But the takeaway point is that the changes in pupil size resulting from a listening task could reflect the effort of executing of verbal responses. found that lessfrequent words elicited higher dilation during verbal responses, suggesting that the construction of the response is another window into the comprehension during listening. For this reason, any pupillometry experiment-but particularly those that involve verbal responses-would benefit from pilot testing that establishes the ideal duration of an inter-trial interval that allows the full time course of the pupil response to the task demands to unfold without affecting baseline for the next trial. Commentary on this aspect of design was given by McGarrigle (2015) who found an average of 4.3 seconds (but sometimes up to 7 seconds) for the pupil to return to baseline size following dilations in a speech-picture verification task. It is possible that tasks that do not include visually presented images (as done by McGarrigle) would have a comparable timecourse of recovery to baseline, but extensive studies remain to be done.

[[ Figure 3 here ]] Figure 3. Proportional change in pupil dilation as listeners hear a sequence of a sentence followed by three random digits in the 2 seconds following the sentence. Colored lines differentiate conditions in which participants repeated only the sentence (gray line) or repeated the sentence and the digits (purple line). Features highlighted from the text include the earlieronset peak in dilation for the sentence-alone condition only for the listeners with normal hearing, and the sustained dilation for listeners with cochlear implants for the sentence & digits condition during the verbal response. Data adapted from the study by Winn & Moore (2018).

div.head: The precision of effort at moments in time
div.p: For effort to be deployed efficiently, it would be elevated at times when there is relatively more reward, and withheld when the reward is lower. In speech perception the reward should scale with the usefulness of the signal. Although the momentary scaling of reward is not customary in speech perception experiments, it is more common in animal studies involving more basic tasks. For example, de Gee et al. 2022 A study by Winn and Moore (2018) inadvertently revealed some insight on the planned timing of effort in a sentence-recognition task. Listeners heard sentences that were each followed by a sequence of three random digits, but with one of two different sets of instructions.

In one condition, the listeners had to repeat the sentence and ignore the digits, while in the other condition they needed to repeat back both the sentence and the digits. The structure of the auditory stimuli was identical across conditions, allowing for a fair comparison of pupil dilation responses that were attributable to the task rather than acoustic or linguistic differences in the stimuli. For the ignored-digits condition, the dilation response for listeners with normal hearing was shifted toward the earlier portion of the trialconsistent with allocating effort where it was most needed during the sentenceand then dropped down during the irrelevant digits (see Figure 3 left panel). Conversely, when the sentence and subsequent digits were both repeated, there was a shallower slope leading up to the peak dilation, possibly suggesting a planned spread of effort across the longer duration of the stimulus sequence. For listeners who use cochlear implants (right panel of Figure 3), there were differences in post-peak dilation, but no pattern of effort reallocation during listening. Although that study was not designed to specifically investigate the temporal precision of cognitive control, the data suggest a topic that might be deserving of further scrutiny: does the effort of listening with hearing impairment include a disruption of the timing of when effort can be efficiently allocated and deployed?
Peak latency as a signature of prediction

The latency of peak dilation could be used as a proxy for the listener's ability to predict when the stimulus will end. This could be observed in Figure 3 above, as the peak latency was two seconds later for stimuli that demanded an extra two seconds of auditory attention compared to the condition where speech in those two seconds could be ignored. In that study and also in two studies where speech was presented at either faster or slower rates, the timing of peak dilation is observed at roughly 0.7 seconds after the offset of the attended stimulus, regardless of speaking rate (Winn & Teece 2020; Borghini & Hazan 2020). Such reliability of peak latency opens up new questions about whether listeners exercise volitional control over effortnot only in magnitude, but also across time. An important caveat to these results is that the speaking rate (or instructions to attend/ignore) was consistent within trial blocks; perhaps the stability of peak latency depends on some amount of consistency in the stimulus or the listener's aptitude for predicting the timecourse of an utterance. A listener's need to predict how long they'll need to pay attention might be a source of effort that goes overlooked in testing designs where such an ability is not needed.

div.head: Lack of pattern as a useful observation
div.p: In the aforementioned sentence recognition study by Winn and Moore (2018), the illustration of data from four experimental conditions were split across separate figure panels to aid visibilityparticularly because the data from CI listeners were not clearly differentiable and thus rather messy when presented on a single figure. Conversely, data from the normal hearing listeners were tightly stacked in an orderly fashion, with clear differences in timing and magnitude. In hindsight, splitting the data might have made an important insight less visible. Figure 4 shows that responses for both listener groups with data from the sequence of four experiment conditions together on the same panel. As a caveat, the number of listeners in each group was both different and small, with 10 normal-hearing listeners and 18 cochlear implant users. Still, the lack of orderly differences in the CI group could indicate that the underlying problem is not necessarily the "amount" of effort, but the lack of control or consistency over when more or less effort is deployed.

[[ Figure 4 here ]] Figure 4. Proportional change in pupil dilation over time for listeners with normal hearing (left) or with cochlear implants (right) when listening to and repeating sentences. The two seconds between sentence and verbal response were filled by either silence, babble noise, digits (ignored) or digits that were repeated along with the sentence. Featured highlighted from the text include the orderly nature of the data in terms of timing and magnitude for the NH listers, and the lack of such orderliness in the CI data. Data adapted from the study by Winn & Moore (2018).

div.head: Dilation on short time scales (momentary changes)
div.p: Pupil dilations can be analyzed on short timescales to determine relative timing and effortfulness of individual processing eventsas illustrated in Figure 1 panel G. For example, pupils dilate upon the detection of a phonetic anomaly (Scheepers 2013;Tamási et al. 2017;Wagner 2019) and timing of such dilations is reliably different than the detection of mere acoustic anomaly. Figure 5 illustrates a zoomed-in look at how changes in pupil dilation are tied to specific events in a study by Winn and Teece (2021). Acoustic disturbances such as noise in the midst of continuous speech elicits increased dilation at 0.7 seconds after the onset of the noise, while phonetic anomalies (mispronunciations of a word in the speech) elicit increased dilation about 1.1 seconds following the mispronounced phoneme. This difference likely reflects the need to hear the full word unfold over time before realizing that it was mispronounced (the average duration of the target word in this study was 390 milliseconds).
[[ Figure 5 here ]] Data adapted from a study by Winn & Teece (2021).

Realigning pupil data to individual stimulus events can reveal subtle dilation patterns that would be lost when averaging across full-sentence stimuli with variable durations. For example, pupil dilations can be linked with the timing of individual masked words in a sentence, as shown in data collected by Smith and Winn (unpublished) presented in Figure 6. In this study, sentences were either presented with all the words intact, or with a single word replaced by noise either at sentence offset or earlier in the sentence (the second, third or fourth word).

Corresponding pupil dilation occurred reliably just after the onset of the masked word regardless of being early or late in the sentence. The patterns from these two different word-recovery types highlight the capability of pupil dilations to track landmarks of perceptual-cognitive events within a single sentence stimulus, to see how quickly different perceptual-cognitive decisions are initiated and resolved.
[[ Figure 6 here ]]

div.head: Dilation on longer time scales
div.p: A large number of studies measure pupil dilations on a short time scale, usually in response to a single stimulus (see review by Zekveld et al. 2018), but it is possible to extend the window of analysis to examine effort on a time scale of a minute or more, as illustrated in Figure 1 panel H. Zhao et al. (2019) presented listeners with an easy, medium, or hard version of a task, which predictably elicited systematically higher initial pupil dilations. Notably, they also observed sustained increased pupil size in the harder task, whereas the easy task elicited dilations that either returned to baseline or shrank even smaller than baseline. In addition to the comparison across task difficulty, they also observed a similar comparison when inspecting data from younger or older participants, where pupil size shrank for the younger listeners across the course of the experiment while staying relatively stable for the older listeners. McGarrigle et al.

(2021a) extended this pattern to speech perception, showing that dilations for a younger group of listeners shrank across a 60-trial session, while the corresponding dilations for the older listener group reduced at a slower pace, implying a difference in the effort evoked by sustained listening. A similar pattern was observed by Ayasse and Wingfield (2020), across 160 trials, and also in a study by Seifi Ala et al. (2020) for 30-second continuous streams of speech. By binning data into 10-trial groups, Brown et al. (2020) found that phasic dilations decreased over the course of the experiment, particularly when the speech as heard by listeners who were nonnative speakers (they began at a much higher peak dilation).

A traditional view of time-aligned and averaged phasic dilations would overlook the patterns described above, highlighting the potential to extend the method beyond single-trial evoked dilations. The results by Ayasse and Wingfield (2020) are especially notable since the slope of the pupil baseline decay was strikingly different across listener groups whose intelligibility scores showed comparatively similar rates of change, suggesting fatigue of maintaining similar performance despite impaired hearing.

Comparison of pupil responses across two testing sessions is another potential window into changes in effort that occur over a longer time scale. For example, a study by Zekveld et al. (2014) compared responses in two listening sessions as participants heard speech in noise. In the second session, there was significantly smaller pupil dilations, for which the authors offered multiple viable explanations. In the second session, the task was more familiar (and thus potentially easier), and it was also more passive (requiring less active decision making and planning). An alternative explanation could be that participants were more fatigued in the second session, as demonstrated in a study by McGarrigle et al. (2017), who observed smaller dilations in the second of two testing blocks, particularly for more difficult trials.

Phasic pupillary responses to multiple consecutive sentences are complicated to interpret, since they can be affected by lingering dilations from the previous stimulus, linguistic/semantic interaction between sentences. However, the baseline pupil size itself can be a source of insight, as suggested by a study by Zhang et al. (2021). Listeners heard 10 consecutive words in conditions that demanded either repetition plus recall or simple repetition. Baseline pupil size was larger for the repeat-and-recall condition, and this difference systematically grew across the sequence of ten presentation trials. Extending this type of study to full sentences, Bönitz et al. (2021) found that baseline pupil size steadily increased over the course of several trials, and that the rate of this increase was modulated by the task demands. The magnitude of baselinecorrected phasic dilations in this experiment is tricky to interpret since the baseline for sentences later in the task are affected by lingering dilations from the preceding sentence.
Nonetheless, the added value of this design is interpreted by Bönitz et al. to characterize the effort allocated in anticipation of upcoming speech while maintaining memory of recently-heard items.

div.head: Pupillary signs of fatigue
div.p: Fatigue is a common difficulty among people with hearing impairment (Hornsby and Kipp 2016;Alhanbali et al. 2017) but has received relatively little attention in the literature compared to momentary changes in effort that are indexed by phasic pupil dilations or subjective responses immediately after a task. Fatigue is a multidimensional construct that should not be expected to emerge as a single measurement. Hornsby et al. (2021) describe the comprehensive process of developing a tool for measuring fatigue, finding separate cognitive, emotional, physical, and social contributions. However, the intuitive link between momentary effort and fatigue is both tempting to explore and a necessary task in the pursuit of understanding hearing difficulty.

Fatigue can be expressed in the pupils in a variety of ways, including the reduction of phasic responses to a rather unengaging task (Beatty 1982b), and decreased pupil size following a long block of tiring work (Geacintov & Peavler 1974). Lowenstein et al. (1963) suggest that pupillary signatures of fatigue are not expressed in the size of the pupil, but rather in the magnitude of pupillary oscillations. Some attempts have been made to link pupil dilation with long-term fatigue, with mixed results. Alhanbali et al. (2021) found a relationship between self-reported tiredness/drowsiness and smaller pre-stimulus pupil diameter that was statistically detectable at a group level although not clearly reliable on an individual level. In the same study, increased pupil diameter was found to be associated with better task performance, partially replicating the detailed physiological work done by Reimer et al. (2016). Wang et al. (2018) found that smaller peak pupil diameter was associated with increased self-reported fatigue in everyday life. Although the relationship of pupil dilations and fatigue did not clearly emerge in a comparison of hard and easy trials used by McGarrigle et al. (2017), more recent work by McGarrigle et al. (2021b) shows an inverse relationship between tasked-evoked pupil responses and tiredness, suggesting that pupillometry can still be a useful tool in this area.

div.head: Analysis of time course data
div.p: The current paper is not intended to be a tutorial on the statistical analysis of time-series data, for which high-quality resources are already available. There are a variety of approaches for pupil data analysis as illustrated neatly in the second figure of a paper by Książek et al. (2021). Additionally, relatively newer methods such as generalized additive mixed-effects models (GAMMs) have been used for pupillometry data (Lõo et al. 2016;Poretta & Tucker 2019;Boswijk et al. 2020), with an introductory tutorial and demonstration written by van Rijn et al. (2019). Such models can describe the shape and differences between data that change in smooth but non-linear ways over time, such as pupil dilations. These models are also built to account for autocorrelation in the data, since the pupil size at timepoint [t] will be related to the pupil size at timepoint [t-1]. GAMMs also can potentially alleviate the problem of polynomial curve fitting for pupil data, which typically sacrifices fit to the data (especially at the endpoints or moments of abrupt change) or interpretability (since higher-order components such as 5 th -or 6 th -degree functions are rather opaque).

Although it is possible to model changes in pupil dilation as a single complex curve with multiple inflection points (e.g. analysis by McHaney et al. 2021), there might also be utility in breaking down the complex curve into different stages of processing that deserve separate inspection. For example, Widmann et al. (2018) modeled a time series of pupil dilation using two distinct principal components that corresponded to earlier and later processing in an auditory oddball task. Winn & Teece 2020) and others (Piquado et al. 2010;Wendt et al. 2016;Bianchi et al. 2019) have treated the listening portions separately from the preparation & response portion of sentence-repetition experiments. Peelle and Van Engen (2021) further clarify that experimenters should be systematic in selecting time windows of analysis, taking note to guard against bias by preregistering window boundaries before a study is conducted, or at least providing a rational justification for time windowing that is not driven by the attraction to significant statistical effects.
Sufficient pupillometry literature has accumulated to be well informed in making such decisions.

Some analysis techniques can identify brief contributions to effort on a very short time scale, despite the sluggishness of pupil dilation. For example, Weirda et al. 2012and McCloy et al. (2016) showed that a complex curve of pupil dilation data could be deconvolved into various contributions, such as auditory detection plus a more substantial later contribution of a behavioral (button-press) response.

div.head: Interpreting pupil dilations as decision making
div.p: Although pupillometry can reflect basic levels of arousal or general difficulty, an experimenter can be served well by thinking of pupil dilation as a signature of decision making (Cavanaugh et al. 2014;Lempert et al. 2015). Lemke and Besser (2016) encourage readers to consider effort as the use of "extra" mental processing; critical analysis of stimuli is needed to determine whether they allow for the listener to reach for the extra processing that would expend effort. For example, simple tones elicit pupil dilation at suprathreshold levels (Bala et al. 2020), but if a listener is unsure whether the tone was heard, there is no clear decision-making process that could reduce that uncertainty after the fact. Conversely, post-stimulus reasoning might influence the judgment of a sentence, as shown by the reduction of effort elicited by stimuli with coherent syntactic structure, with further reductions by coherent semantic structure (Beatty 1982a). Even when parts of such stimuli are misperceived, decisions about the stimulus could be made easier based on the constraints and probabilities in the language. Given this framework, some studies of listening effort in speech perception might be underpowered if the stimuli do not demand a specific decision that can be influenced by higher-level cognition.

Therefore some of the persistent emphasis in the literature on definitions of effort and refinements of outcome measures (e.g. pupil dilations, EEG oscillations, reaction times, etc.) are incomplete without a corresponding adoption of stimuli that elicit meaningful kinds of mental activity that reflect realistic processes in communication.

Even in the absence of an explicit auditory stimulus, the separation of events into recognition followed by decision was illustrated elegantly by Satterthwaite et al. (2007). They conducted a gambling task in which participants predicted whether a card value will be higher or lower than the previously drawn card. There was an initial dilation upon presentation of the first card, followed by a second dilation whose magnitude reflected the ambiguity of the prediction.

The smallest dilation was elicited by the endpoints 2 and Ace, with slightly more dilation for cards near the endpoint (like 4 or Queen), and most dilation for cards near 8, where a following card is just as likely to be higher as lower. In addition to the differences due to the difficulty of the decision, there were also distinct patterns in dilation resulting from the ultimate success or failure of the judgment, which interacted with the certainty of the choice; the extra dilation observed after a lost trial was even more pronounced when the trial should have been a probable win. The data from this study show a clear relationship between the ambiguity of evidence leading to a decision, and how the changes in pupil dilation are linked to the arrival of information as well as the timing of the decision.

div.head: Differences in task demands helps to explain differences in results
div.p: Studies can appear at first glance to be studying the same topic but vary widely in their patterns of results (i.e. sometimes there's an effect of stimulus degradation, but sometimes not… sometimes there's an effect of masker type, but sometimes not, etc.), which some view as a problem with the measurement. A critical analysis of seemingly discrepant studies reveals insight about the importance of stimulus and task design (Strand & Brown 2022). Systematic degradation of spectral resolution leads to systematic increases in pupil dilation, but only if the stimulus demands the computation of linguistic meaning. For example, the need to formulate responses while still maintaining recall of earlier information might be more effortful for whole sentences (Bönitz et al. 2021), but does not emerge when testing single words in isolation (Zhang et al. 2021). Spectral degradation elicits increased pupil dilation for sentence-length stimuli (Winn et al. 2015;Miles et al. 2017), but no such effects are found for isolated spoken letters (McCloy et al. 2017) or for digit sequences (Milvae et al. 2021). There was no difference in pupil size elicited by different levels of degradation for a task of single word recognition conducted by Colby and McMurray (2021), further highlighting how pupillary signs of effort reflect the resources needed to construct linguistic coherence more strongly than the difficulty of the sensory encoding itself. However, there are also documented effects of phonological neighborhood competition on the recognition of single words, as documented by Kuchinsky et al. (2013).

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: Pupillometry is a useful but complicated measurement of cognitive load that holds potential for analyzing the way that effort changes on a moment-to-moment basis. Numerous studies have shown how pupil dilations can be characterized not just in terms of magnitude, but timing and duration relative to informative stimulus landmarks. There are orderly relationships between stimulus detection and the onset of dilation, as well as a relationship between peak dilation and the expectation that a stimulus will end. The strategic loading of effort at specific times during listening might be a rich area of future research. Insights that emerge from the full time course of pupil dilation evoked by speech, as well as an appreciation of the stimulus factors that might elicit different kinds of cognitive load or decision-making behavior in targeted ways. In each panel, the two lines reflect different hypothetical conditions. Panels A, B, C, and D illustrate dilation patterns that emerge at earlier to later parts of the trial (pre-stimulus baseline, dilation slope, retention interval, verbal response, respectively). Panels E and F illustrate a distinction in dilation latency that is either clearly separated or blended together. Panel G is a full time course that has a particular window of analysis that is expanded into a sub-panel where the subtle differences in dilation onset are observed. Panel H shows a longer time scale of dilations lasting over a minute rather than the ~14 second patterns shown in earlier panels. In panel H, the overall pupil size as well as the size and compactness of phasic dilations all change across multiple trials. between responses for high-and low-context sentences as the rate gets slower, and the overall larger distinction between those stimulus types for listeners with NH. Figure 3. Proportional change in pupil dilation as listeners hear a sequence of a sentence followed by three random digits in the 2 seconds following the sentence. Colored lines differentiate conditions in which participants repeated only the sentence (gray line) or repeated the sentence and the digits (purple line). Features highlighted from the text include the earlieronset peak in dilation for the sentence-alone condition only for the listeners with normal hearing, and the sustained dilation for listeners with cochlear implants for the sentence & digits condition during the verbal response. Data adapted from the study by Winn & Moore (2018). or with cochlear implants (right) when listening to and repeating sentences. The two seconds between sentence and verbal response were filled by either silence, babble noise, digits (ignored) or digits that were repeated along with the sentence. Featured highlighted in the text include the orderly nature of the data in terms of timing and magnitude for the NH listers, and the lack of such orderliness in the CI data. Data adapted from the study by Winn & Moore (2018).

presented multiple 60-trial blocks that alternated in terms of reward for correct responses, and found corresponding elevations in pupil-indexed arousal in mice during the high-reward trials.Figure 1panels E and F illustrate a hypothetical situation in which pupillary responses are either tightly locked to precise moments (E) or loosely spread across those moments (F), suggesting more or less efficient allocation of effort, respectively.

figure.head: Figure 5 .
figure.figDesc: Proportional change in pupil dilation resulting from a word being replaced with noise (red line) or mispronounced (blue line) during a sentence. The black line shows a reference condition with no such distortions. The darker gray shaded area denotes the onset and average offset time of the target word. Dotted lines show approximate times of divergence of the Masked / Mispronounced condition data away from the data from the Intact (regular speech) condition.

figure.head: Figure 6 .
figure.figDesc: Proportional change in pupil dilation during a sentence recognition task. The three stimulus types included a normal intact sentence (dotted black line), a sentence with the final word replaced by noise (blue line), or with an earlier word replaced by noise (orange line). The gray shaded area begins at stimulus offset, and marks the time between stimulus and spoken response form the participant. In each case of single-word masking, the word was recoverable by context elsewhere in the sentence. The bottom panel shows the linear difference between proportions in the upper panel relative to the regular-sentence condition, highlighting the clarity of timing signatures of effort in the pupil data.

figure.head: Figure 6 .
figure.figDesc: Proportional change in pupil dilation during a sentence recognition task. The three stimulus types included a normal intact sentence (dotted black line), a sentence with the final word replaced by noise (blue line), or with an earlier word replaced by noise (orange line). The gray shaded area begins at stimulus offset, and marks the time between stimulus and spoken response form the participant. In each case of single-word masking, the word was recoverable by context elsewhere in the sentence. The bottom panel shows the linear difference between proportions in the upper panel relative to the regular-sentence condition, highlighting the clarity of timing signatures of effort in the pupil data.
